definition: A connection between two bones that allows for movement and provides mechanical support.
A joint where bones are connected by dense connective tissue rich in collagen fibers, allowing little or no movement.
A joint where bones are connected by cartilage, permitting limited movement.
A freely movable joint characterized by a fluid-filled joint cavity enclosed by a joint capsule.
An immovable joint.
A slightly movable joint.
A freely movable joint.
A type of fibrous joint where bones are connected by a ligament or interosseous membrane.
An immovable fibrous joint found between the flat bones of the skull.
A fibrous joint where a conical process fits into a socket, such as a tooth in its alveolus.
A cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage.
A cartilaginous joint where bones are connected by a pad of fibrocartilage.
A thin layer of hyaline cartilage covering the ends of bones in synovial joints.
A sleeve-like structure that encloses a synovial joint, consisting of an outer fibrous layer and an inner synovial membrane.
The inner lining of the joint capsule that secretes synovial fluid.
A lubricating fluid that reduces friction between the articular cartilages during movement.
A crescent-shaped pad of fibrocartilage in some synovial joints that improves fit between articulating bones.
A small fluid-filled sac that reduces friction between moving structures in a joint.
A synovial joint where a spherical head fits into a cup-like socket, allowing movement in all directions.
A synovial joint where an oval condyle fits into an elliptical cavity, permitting movement in two planes.
A synovial joint with flat articulating surfaces that allow sliding or twisting movements.
A synovial joint where a convex surface fits into a concave surface, allowing movement in one plane like a door hinge.
A synovial joint where a cylindrical surface rotates within a ring of bone and ligament, permitting rotational movement.
A synovial joint where articulating surfaces are shaped like saddle seats, allowing movement in two planes.
A movement that decreases the angle between two body parts.
A movement that increases the angle between two body parts.
Extension of a joint beyond its normal range of motion.
Movement at the ankle that brings the foot closer to the shin.
Movement at the ankle that points the foot downward away from the shin.
Moving a limb away from the midline of the body.
Moving a limb toward the midline of the body.
Turning a bone around its own longitudinal axis.
Moving a limb in a circular motion, combining flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction.
Rotation of the forearm so the palm faces upward or forward.
Rotation of the forearm so the palm faces downward or backward.
Turning the sole of the foot inward.
Turning the sole of the foot outward.
Moving a body part forward parallel to the ground.
Moving a body part backward parallel to the ground.
Raising a body part vertically.
Lowering a body part vertically.
A band of dense connective tissue that connects bones and supports joints.
The fixed attachment point of a muscle.
The movable attachment point of a muscle.
A ball-and-socket joint between the humerus and scapula, allowing a wide range of motion.
A group of muscles and tendons that stabilize the shoulder joint.
A hinge joint between the humerus and ulna, and a pivot joint between the humerus and radius.
A ball-and-socket joint between the femur and the pelvis, designed for stability and weight-bearing.
A complex hinge joint involving the femur, tibia, and patella, allowing flexion and extension.
A key ligament that helps stabilize the knee joint.
C-shaped fibrocartilaginous discs in the knee that absorb shock.
Inflammation of a bursa, causing pain and restricted movement.
Inflammation of joints resulting in pain and stiffness.
A degenerative joint disease caused by the breakdown of cartilage.
An autoimmune disorder causing chronic inflammation of joints.
A form of arthritis characterized by severe pain due to uric acid crystal accumulation.
A diagnostic test examining joint fluid to detect diseases.
An injury involving the stretching or tearing of ligaments.
Abnormal stiffness or immobility of a joint due to fusion of the bones.
A ligament of the hip joint connecting the femur to the acetabulum.
A ring of cartilage that deepens the socket of the hip joint.
A fibrocartilaginous rim attached to the margin of a joint cavity.
A condition characterized by decreased bone mass, leading to fragile bones.
